<Summary source="https://www.fxempire.com/macro/namibia/inflation-rate">
## Summary of Article

**Source:** Fxempire  
**Date:** January 18, 2023

### Key Facts and Statistics:

**Most Recent Data (December 2025):**
- Annual inflation rate: 3.2% (down from 3.4% in November 2025)
- This represents the softest inflation rate since August 2025
- This marks the second consecutive month of easing inflation
- Monthly CPI change: +0.1% in December (compared to 0.0% flat in November)

**Historical Context:**
- Highest inflation rate: 20.54% (June 1992)
- Lowest inflation rate: 0.94% (May 2005)
- Average inflation rate: 8.75% (1973-2025 period)
- Data frequency: Monthly
- Next release date: February 12, 2026

**CPI Category Breakdown by Weight:**
- Housing and Utilities: 28.4% (most important category)
- Food and Non-Alcoholic Beverages: 16.5%
- Transport: 14.3%
- Alcoholic Beverages and Tobacco: 12.6%
- Furnishings and Household Equipment: 5.5%
- Miscellaneous Goods and Services: 5.4%
- Other categories (Communication, Education, Recreation and Culture, Clothing and Footwear, Health, Hotels/Cafés/Restaurants): 17.6% combined

**December 2025 Price Changes by Category (year-on-year):**
- Food & non-alcoholic beverages: 2.6% (slowed from 3.9% in November)
- Hotels, cafes & restaurants: 4.2% (slowed from 4.8%)
- Alcoholic beverages & tobacco: 3.7% (slowed from 3.9%)
- Housing & utilities: 4.5% (accelerated from 4.1%)
- Recreation & culture: 4.3% (accelerated from 3.8%)

**Note:** The article date appears inconsistent with the data presented (article dated January 2023 but contains December 2025 data).
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.theglobaleconomy.com/Namibia/inflation_annual/">
# Summary of Article on Namibia's Inflation Data

## Key Facts and Statistics:

**Most Recent Inflation Data (as of article date):**
- December 2025: 3.19% (annual inflation rate)
- November 2025: 3.36%
- October 2025: 3.61%
- September 2025: 3.49%
- August 2025: 3.23%
- July 2025: 3.53%
- June 2025: 3.66%
- May 2025: 3.46%

**Historical Context:**
- Historical average for Namibia (February 2012 to December 2025): 4.81%
- Historical minimum: 1.64% (April 2020)
- Historical maximum: 8.2% (January 2017)

**Other Economic Indicators (for context):**
- Monthly inflation (December 2025): 0.08%
- Consumer Price Index (December 2025): 177.9688 index points
- USD exchange rate (January 2026): 16.2906 Local Currency Units per USD

**Data Source:** Namibia Statistics Agency

## Observations:
The article shows a declining trend in annual inflation from mid-2025 through December 2025, with the rate dropping from 3.66% in June to 3.19% in December. The current inflation rates are below the historical average of 4.81%.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://thebrief.com.na/2026/01/namibia-inflation-eases-to-3-2-in-december-on-slower-food-prices/">
# Summary of Article: Namibia inflation eases to 3.2% in December on slower food prices

**Key Statistics and Facts:**

- **December 2025 headline annual inflation**: 3.2%, down from 3.4% in December 2024
- **Monthly inflation (December 2025)**: 0.1%, up from 0.0% the previous month
- **Core inflation**: 3.4%, marginally higher than the headline rate of 3.2%
- **Average inflation rate for 2025**: 3.5%

**Sectoral Breakdown:**

- **Food inflation**: Slowed to 2.6% from 5.9% a year earlier
  - Bread and cereals: -0.5% (deflation)
  - Oils and fats: +2.9%
  - Fish: +2.2%
  - Sugar and confectionery: +2.4%

- **Housing, water, electricity, gas and other fuels**: Contributed 1.1 percentage points to overall inflation, with annual increase of 4.5%
  - Electricity, gas and other fuels specifically rose from 1.4% to 4.5%

- **Food and non-alcoholic beverages**: Contributed 0.5 percentage points
- **Alcoholic beverages and tobacco**: Contributed 0.5 percentage points, with overall inflation of 3.7%
  - Tobacco prices: +5.3%
  - Alcoholic beverages: +3.3%

- **Transport**: 2.0% annual inflation (reversing -1.4% deflation in December 2024), driven by higher fuel prices and vehicle service/repair costs

- **Goods inflation**: 2.7%
- **Services inflation**: 4.0%

**Regional Variations:**

- Zone 2 (Khomas Region): 3.3% (highest)
- Zone 3: 3.2%
- Zone 1 (northern regions): 3.0% (lowest)
- Petrol prices: N$21.21/liter in Zone 3 (highest), N$20.93/liter in Zone 1 (lowest)

**Source Attribution:**
Data from Namibia Statistics Agency (NSA) Consumer Price Index bulletin, with quotes from NSA Statistician-General and CEO Alex Shimuafeni.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.observer24.com.na/ean-warns-economic-growth-will-not-translate-into-jobs/">
# Summary of Article: "EAN warns economic growth will not translate into jobs"

**Source:** Observer24.com.na  
**Date:** January 29, 2026

## Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **Economic Growth Forecasts:**
   - Bank of Namibia forecasts GDP growth of approximately 3% in 2025
   - Growth expected to accelerate to 3.9% in 2026, assuming stronger sectoral performance and stable external environment

2. **Inflation Data:**
   - Headline inflation eased to 3.2% in December 2025, down from 3.4% a year earlier
   - The decline was driven mainly by slower food price increases
   - Source: Namibia Statistics Agency (NSA) consumer price index

3. **Global Context:**
   - IMF projects global growth of approximately 3.3% in 2026
   - Global inflation is easing
   - Interest rates are moderating

## Key Opinions from Named/Reliable Sources:

**Economic Association of Namibia (EAN):**
- Warns that while macroeconomic outlook for 2026 appears positive, it remains narrow and vulnerable
- Economic performance heavily dependent on a small number of sectors, favorable weather conditions, and limited fiscal space
- Growth of around 3% unlikely to create enough jobs to significantly reduce unemployment, especially among youth
- Much of the country's growth concentrated in capital-intensive sectors that generate limited employment
- Poverty reduction expected to remain slow and uneven
- Government's capacity to expand social programs constrained by fiscal pressures, particularly if SACU and diamond revenues weaken

**Bank of Namibia:**
- Expects economic growth to improve in 2026 after subdued 2025 performance

**International Monetary Fund (IMF):**
- Cautioned that uncertainty remains high due to trade tensions, geopolitical risks, and uneven growth across regions

## Additional Context:

- Total Energies expected to consider final investment decision on Namibia's oil and gas prospects in second half of 2026
- Diamond revenues remain exposed to global market shifts and changing consumer preferences
- Manufacturing sector remains under pressure
- EAN emphasizes need for shift towards labor-intensive sectors (construction, housing, tourism, hospitality, agriculture, agro-processing, retail, logistics, services)
</Summary>

Query: What will be Namibia's annual inflation rate for March 2026?
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Market Calm Lowers Inflation Forecast for 2026, According to Focus Bulletin**
The market's expectation for Brazil's official inflation rate, measured by the IPCA, was revised downward to 3.99% for 2026, a reduction from 4.00%, according to the weekly Boletim Focus published by the Central Bank on February 2, 2026. This marks the fourth consecutive week of downward revision and keeps the forecast within the target range set by the Monetary Council National (CMN), which is 3% with a tolerance margin of 1.5% to 4.5%. For 2027, the inflation expectation remains at 3.8%, while for 2028 and 2029, the market projects a stable 3.5% annual inflation rate. Short-term projections show inflation expected to rise 0.53% in February and 0.34% in March. The IGP-M, a key index for rent adjustments, saw its 2026 projection increase slightly from 3.87% to 3.92%. Prices for administered goods saw a minor decline, from 3.76% to 3.75%. Economic activity projections remained stable, with GDP growth forecast at 1.8% for 2026 and 2% for 2027. The market expects a gradual decline in the benchmark interest rate (Selic), projecting it to fall to 12.25% by the end of 2026, down from 14.5% in March, with a further drop to 10.5% by the end of 2027. The dollar exchange rate is projected to close 2026 at R$ 5.50, with a slight downward revision to R$ 5.38 for February. Fiscal projections indicate improvement in public debt, with the net public debt ratio forecast to decrease from 70.36% to 70.32% of GDP in 2026. The primary deficit is expected to remain at -0.53% of GDP, and the nominal deficit at -8.6%. The external sector forecast shows a continued trade surplus of US$ 67.65 billion in 2026, while foreign direct investment was revised downward from US$ 74.85 billion to US$ 74.35 billion. The current account deficit is projected to slightly widen from US$ -67.8 billion to US$ -67.9 billion.
Original language: pt
Publish date: February 02, 2026 05:52 PM
Source:[Correio Braziliense](https://www.correiobraziliense.com.br/economia/2026/02/7345902-mercado-calmo-reduz-projecao-de-inflacao-para-2026-aponta-boletim-focus.html)

**Austria's Inflation Forecast: 2026 Projection at 2.2% Amid Government Measures and Statistical Effects**
According to a new calculation by the Institute for Higher Studies (IHS), Austria's annual inflation rate is projected to decrease from 3.6% in 2025 to 2.2% in 2026. This forecast, presented by Economics Minister Wolfgang Hattmannsdorfer and Finance State Secretary Barbara Eibinger-Miedl, reflects a 'technical update' incorporating various measures that have taken effect or will take effect in 2026. These include the reduction of the electricity levy starting January 1, 2026 (contributing 0.12–0.16 percentage points), the Austria electricity tariff from Verbund starting in March, price reductions by EVN, and a new social tariff from April. The rent control measure is expected to reduce inflation by 0.13 percentage points, and the reduction in food VAT by 0.1–0.2 percentage points. A significant portion of the decline—approximately 0.8 percentage points—is attributed to the statistical effect of the energy aid phase-out in 2025 no longer being included in 2026's inflation calculation. The combined effect of these measures is projected to save an average household around 900 euros annually. The first official inflation data for January 2026, to be released on February 4, is expected to show a rate of 2.4–2.5%, down from 3.8% in December 2025. Officials from the Austrian government, including Hattmannsdorfer and Eibinger-Miedl, believe 2026 could be the 'year of the turnaround' and emphasize the need to maintain momentum in implementing further measures.
Original language: de
Publish date: February 02, 2026 05:01 PM
Source:[Heute.at](https://www.heute.at/s/erste-berechnung-da-so-soll-inflation-heuer-sinken-120159536)

**Market Lowers Inflation Forecast to 3.99% for 2026, Maintains Growth and Interest Rate Projections**
The market's forecast for Brazil's official inflation rate, the National Consumer Price Index (IPCA), has been revised downward from 4% to 3.99% for 2026, according to the weekly Focus report published by the Central Bank (BC) in Brasília. The projection for 2027 remains unchanged at 3.8%, while inflation is expected to be 3.5% in both 2028 and 2029. The 2026 forecast is within the Central Bank's inflation target range of 3% ±1.5 percentage points (1.5% to 4.5%). The first official IPCA data for 2026 will be released on February 10 by the Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics (IBGE), covering January's price changes. In December 2025, inflation rose to 0.33% due to increases in ride-hailing and airfare prices, contributing to a 4.26% annual rise in 2025. The benchmark interest rate (Selic), currently set at 15% per year by the Central Bank's Monetary Policy Committee (Copom), has not been adjusted for five consecutive meetings despite declining inflation and exchange rates. The Copom confirmed it will begin reducing rates in March if inflation remains under control. Market analysts expect the Selic to fall to 12.25% by the end of 2026, 10.5% in 2027, 10% in 2028, and 9.5% in 2029. The economy's growth forecast for 2026 and 2027 remains at 1.8%, with expectations of 2% growth in 2028 and 2029. In the third quarter of 2025, the economy grew 0.1%, indicating stability, following a 3.4% increase in 2024—the fourth consecutive year of growth and the highest since 2021. The consolidated 2025 GDP data is scheduled for release on March 3. The dollar's projected exchange rate is R$5.50 for the end of 2026 and 2027.
Original language: pt
Publish date: February 02, 2026 02:58 PM
Source:[Jovem Pan – Esportes, entretenimento, notícias e vídeos com credibilidade](https://jovempan.com.br/noticias/economia/mercado-reduz-previsao-da-inflacao-para-399-em-2026.html)

**Market Lowers 2026 Inflation Expectation to 3.99% and Maintains 2027 Forecast**
The market's expectation for inflation in 2026, measured by the IPCA, decreased by 0.01 percentage point to 3.99%, according to the Central Bank's Focus survey released on February 2, 2026. For 2027, the inflation projection remains unchanged at 3.80%, still significantly above the official target center of 3% with a tolerance margin of ±1.5 percentage points. Analysts continue to expect the Selic rate to begin cutting in March, with a 0.5 percentage point reduction, bringing the rate from its current 15% to 12.25% by the end of 2026 and 10.50% by the end of 2027. GDP growth projections for both 2026 and 2027 remain steady at 1.80%. The exchange rate projection for the end of 2026 stayed unchanged for the 16th consecutive week at R$5.50. For 2027, the projection was slightly adjusted upward by 0.01 percentage point to R$5.50. In January 2026, the U.S. dollar depreciated by approximately 5.5% against the real, nearly half the 12.2% depreciation seen in all of 2025, when the dollar closed at R$5.47. In the previous month, the real recorded the second-largest appreciation against the dollar among 28 monitored currencies, according to the Elos Ayta report, with 22 of the 28 currencies also appreciating.
Original language: pt
Publish date: February 02, 2026 12:29 PM
Source:[Istoe dinheiro](https://istoedinheiro.com.br/mercado-expectativa-inflacao-em-2026-399)

**Analysts Now Expect Inflation Below 4% This Year, Focus Survey Shows**
Analysts surveyed by the Central Bank revised their inflation forecast for 2026 downward to 3.99%, below the 4% threshold, according to the weekly Focus survey released by the Central Bank on February 2, 2026. The projection for inflation in 2027 remains unchanged at 3.80%. The official inflation target center is 3.00%, with a tolerance margin of ±1.5 percentage points. No changes were observed in GDP growth forecasts, which remain at 1.80% for both 2026 and 2027. Analysts continue to expect the benchmark Selic interest rate to end 2026 at 12.25% and 2027 at 10.50%. The first rate cut, currently at 15%, is still anticipated in March 2026, with a 0.5 percentage point reduction expected.
Original language: pt
Publish date: February 02, 2026 11:56 AM
Source:[Investing.com Brasil](https://br.investing.com/news/forex-news/analistas-passam-a-ver-inflacao-este-ano-abaixo-de-4-mostra-focus-1818564)

**Marcowa emerytura w górę, a pierwsze wypłaty jeszcze w lutym! Zobacz wyliczenia**
The annual adjustment of pensions in Poland, known as 'waloryzacja', is a mechanism that determines the increase in benefits paid by ZUS (Polish Social Insurance Institution). For 2026, the government has projected a 4.88% adjustment rate, based on two components: inflation and the real growth of average wages. The data for these components is provided by the Central Statistical Office (GUS) in February, enabling ZUS to issue increased pensions starting March 1, 2026. The current minimum pension is 1,878.91 zł; with a 4.88% increase, it will rise by approximately 91.70 zł, reaching about 1,970.61 zł. This adjustment reflects the variable nature of inflation and wage growth, which are determined annually through negotiations within the Social Dialogue Council in June. In 2024, the adjustment rate was 12.12%, driven by high inflation. The 2026 rate assumes a 20% weight for real wage growth, as decided by the government in July 2025.
Original language: pl
Publish date: February 02, 2026 08:06 AM
Source:[Poznań Nasze Miasto](https://poznan.naszemiasto.pl/w-marcu-podwyzka-od-zus-sprawdz-jak-prognozuje-sie-waloryzacja-w-2026-roku-tyle-zus-przeleje-na-konto/ar/c3p2-28252071)

**Pension Indexation in 2026: Some Retirees to Receive Higher Benefits in February**
In February 2026, retirees and pensioners will receive their last payments at the current amounts, as the next pension adjustment will take effect on March 1. Millions of recipients will see higher payouts starting in March due to the annual pension indexation. The timing benefits some individuals, as March 1 falls on a Sunday, allowing those whose payment date is the 1st of the month to receive their increased benefits in February. This mirrors a prior situation in February 2026, when some received their payments on January 30 due to the first of the month falling on a Sunday. The final indexation rate remains pending, to be published by the Central Statistical Office on February 9, 2026. The adjustment is based on two factors: inflation for retirees, which was 4.2% (higher than the national average of 3.6%), and the real growth in average wages. The projected indexation rate for 2026 is approximately 5.08%, resulting in a gross increase of 95.45 zł for minimum pensions, though this is lower than previous years with double-digit inflation.
Original language: pl
Publish date: February 02, 2026 07:47 AM
Source:[Interia.pl - Biznes](https://biznes.interia.pl/emerytury/news-marcowa-waloryzacja-emerytur-niektorzy-dostana-wyzsze-swiadc,nId,22546096)

**Inflation Slowed in January Amid Launch of New IPC, But Challenges Loom for February**
The inflation rate in January 2026 is expected to have slowed compared to December's 2.8%, according to private consulting firms. FIEL forecasts a 2.1% increase, Equilibra 2.2%, Analytica and EcoGo both 2.4%. This would mark the first intermonthly deceleration since May 2025, when inflation began rising from 1.5% toward nearly doubling. Despite this, the median forecast of 2.4% implies an annual inflation rate of 2.4%—slightly higher than January 2025's 2.2%, indicating ongoing inflationary pressure. The new Consumer Price Index (IPC), launched by the National Institute of Statistics and Census (Indec) under Marco Lavagna, replaces the outdated 2004–2005 household expenditure survey with a 2017–2018 version, aiming for greater accuracy. While the new IPC would have slightly increased the 2025 inflation rate (32.2% vs. 31.5% under the old method), Equilibra and EcoGo confirm that January’s inflation rate would be the same under both systems—2.4%—a favorable outcome for the government. This suggests the new methodology did not trigger a spike in reported inflation. Key drivers in January included recreation (3.4% by EcoGo) and restaurants/hotels (3.8% by Equilibra), both affected by seasonal holiday demand, along with food prices rising 2.4% to 3.1%. In contrast, education and clothing saw minimal increases or even deflation (−1.6% for clothing, per Equilibra). The true test will come in March with February’s inflation data, as the new IPC gives greater weight to energy tariffs—already rising due to subsidy cuts starting January 16, including a 16% gas price hike effective February. The government hopes that any acceleration in energy costs will be offset by a potential slowdown in food inflation, which now has reduced weight in the new index.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 02, 2026 03:09 AM
Source:[El Destape](https://www.eldestapeweb.com/economia/inflacion/la-inflacion-bajo-en-enero-con-el-debut-del-nuevo-ipc-del-indec-2026220552)

**South African Reserve Bank holds interest rates steady: Implications for the property market**
The South African Reserve Bank (SARB) held its policy rate unchanged at 6.75% during its February 1, 2026, Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) meeting, citing balanced inflation risks and ongoing services inflation above 4%, despite goods inflation at 3% and core goods at 1.2%. Governor Lesetja Kganyago stated that while low goods inflation is supported by a stronger rand, services inflation remains a concern, and the MPC decided to maintain stability, with two members favoring a 25 basis point cut and four preferring a hold. Property industry leaders expressed mixed reactions: Adrian Goslett of REMAX Southern Africa welcomed the stability, noting it supports short-term market confidence, though many hoped for a rate cut to improve affordability. Samuel Seeff of Seeff Property Group called the decision 'hugely disappointing' and a 'missed opportunity,' arguing that domestic economic improvements—such as lower unemployment and stronger growth signals—justify a cut, especially since the current rate remains above pre-pandemic levels. He highlighted that transaction volumes in 2025 (18,302) are 26.5% lower than in 2021 (23,154), and emphasized that 4-5% sustained growth is needed to address unemployment, urging the SARB to act decisively by March 2026. Dr Andrew Golding of Pam Golding Property Group noted that while the decision was not what borrowers hoped for, market demand remains steady, with housing shortages in high-demand areas and signs of recovery in Gauteng, and investment demand for buy-to-rent properties is surging. Toni Anderson of Standard Bank observed that earlier rate cuts have already improved affordability and buyer sentiment, with increased home loan applications and stable pricing encouraging balanced market activity. She concluded that the current rate stability allows households time to adjust and supports a sustained recovery in select regions.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 01, 2026 04:10 PM
Source:[IOL](https://iol.co.za/business-report/economy/2026-02-01-south-african-reserve-bank-holds-interest-rates-steady-implications-for-the-property-market/)

**South Africa's interest rates remain unchanged: What to expect in 2026?**
South Africa's interest rates remain unchanged at 6.75% following the South African Reserve Bank's (SARB) January 29, 2026, Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) meeting, with the prime lending rate staying at 10.25%. Four MPC members voted to maintain the rate, while two supported a 25-basis-point cut. This decision followed a slight rise in December's headline Consumer Price Inflation (CPI) to 3.6% from November's 3.5%. SARB Governor Lesetja Kganyago suggested the December figure may represent the 'peak' and expressed optimism that inflation will ease through 2026. Analysts, including Nolan Wapenaar of Anchor Capital, project approximately three more 0.25% rate cuts by mid-2027, based on the SARB's Quarterly Projection Model (QPM), which anticipates a shift from a slightly restrictive to a neutral monetary policy stance. However, risks remain: services and food inflation exceed 4%, driven by a foot-and-mouth disease outbreak and electricity price miscalculations by NERSA, which could lead to a R76 billion revenue shortfall. In 2025, inflation reached 3.2%, the lowest in 21 years. Investec economist Lara Hodes noted that inflation expectations have eased, with a projected 2026 inflation rate of 3.3%, down from 3.5%, though upside risks persist, particularly from electricity prices. Bradd Bendall of BetterBond anticipates further cuts, citing inflation within one percentage point of the 3% target and a stable rand. The SARB aims to align inflation with projections ahead of the March 2026 MPC meeting.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 30, 2026 03:41 PM
Source:[IOL](https://iol.co.za/sunday-tribune/news/2026-01-30-south-africas-interest-rates-remain-unchanged-what-to-expect-in-2026/)

**Namibia: The 2025/2026 Proposed Tax Measures**
Financial advisory firm Simonis Storm predicts a 25 basis point interest rate cut by the Bank of Namibia in the first quarter of 2026, contingent on inflation remaining within the target range and financial stability being maintained. The last data, released in November 2025, showed inflation at 3.4% year on year, comfortably within the Bank of Namibia's target band. The analysts note that although the pace of monetary easing will be cautious, current monetary conditions continue to support credit extension and economic activity, particularly as liquidity normalizes following the Eurobond redemption. The first repo rate announcement is scheduled for February 2026.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 09, 2026 05:43 PM
Source:[allAfrica](https://allafrica.com/stories/202601090422.html)

**Namibia**
Namibia's Consumer Price Index (CPI) increased by 0.10% in December 2025, marking a slight rise from November 2025's flat 0.00% growth, according to data updated on January 8, 2026. This minimal uptick signals a gentle month-over-month increase in consumer prices, indicating subtle economic shifts. The change, while restrained, suggests possible early signs of rising consumer demand or adjusting supply constraints as the country emerges from a period of price stabilization. Economists and market analysts are expected to monitor the CPI's underlying components for insights into the sectors driving the change. The modest increase may influence future fiscal and monetary policy decisions as Namibia navigates its economic trajectory in 2026.

**Namibia Holds Rates As South Africa's Policy Shift Limits Room to Cut**
Namibia's central bank maintained its key interest rate at 6.50% on December 14, 2025, citing the need to preserve the one-to-one currency peg with the South African rand amid tightening policy conditions in South Africa. South Africa's adoption of a stricter 3% inflation target has increased pressure on Namibia to prioritize domestic price stability to safeguard the exchange-rate arrangement. The Bank of Namibia noted that South Africa’s benchmark rate remains slightly higher, and narrowing the gap too quickly could trigger capital outflows and strain the peg. Despite easing inflation risks, the central bank held rates steady. The bank revised its 2025 economic growth forecast downward to 3% from 3.5%, citing weak performance in manufacturing and diamond mining. Inflation expectations were slightly revised down due to a firmer currency outlook and lower projected oil prices. The decision marked the final meeting under outgoing Governor Johannes!Gawaxab, whose successor has not yet been named, adding uncertainty to future monetary policy continuity. The case underscores how currency-pegged economies like Namibia face limited policy independence, with monetary decisions closely tied to South Africa’s framework despite domestic economic headwinds. Diamond mining remains a structural vulnerability, and manufacturing has not yet emerged as a reliable growth driver. Policymakers are prioritizing monetary stability over short-term stimulus, even as growth slows and inflation pressures ease.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 14, 2025 05:21 PM
Source:[allAfrica](https://allafrica.com/stories/202512140029.html)

**Namibia central bank cuts repo rate to support weakening economy**
Namibia's central bank, the Bank of Namibia, reduced its main interest rate by 25 basis points to 6.50% on October 15, 2025, citing a weakening domestic economy and well-contained inflation. This marks the first rate cut in three consecutive monetary policy meetings, during which the rate had remained unchanged. The move aims to support economic activity while preserving the currency peg between the Namibian dollar and the South African rand. Governor Johannes!Gawaxab stated that although the rate cut widens the gap with South Africa’s 7% repo rate, the difference remains within levels where capital flows are expected to stay stable. Inflation rose slightly to 3.5% year-on-year in September from 3.2% in August. The central bank revised its inflation projections downward by 0.2 percentage points for 2025 (to 3.6%) and 2026 (to 4.0%), citing a revised outlook for lower oil prices. It maintained its GDP growth forecasts at 3.5% for 2025 and 3.9% for 2026.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 15, 2025 11:51 AM
Source:[Zawya.com](https://www.zawya.com/en/economy/africa/namibia-central-bank-cuts-repo-rate-to-support-weakening-economy-v371l6so)

**Bank of Namibia Lowers Key Rate to 6.5% | Forex News 2025.10.15...**
In its October 2025 meeting, the Bank of Namibia reduced its benchmark repo rate by 25 basis points to 6.5%, aiming to support the domestic economy while maintaining the fixed currency peg between the Namibia Dollar and the South African Rand. The decision follows a slowdown in annual GDP growth, which declined to 1.6% in the second quarter of 2025—down from 2.8% in the first quarter—driven by weak performance in manufacturing, fishing, and agriculture. As a result, economic growth for 2025 is now projected to fall from 3.7% in 2024, with increasing downside risks. Despite this, inflation has remained under control, averaging 3.6% through the first eight months of 2025. Inflation forecasts for 2025 and 2026 have been revised downward by 0.2 percentage points to 3.6% and 4.0%, respectively, based on expectations of a stronger exchange rate and lower oil price forecasts.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 15, 2025 10:02 AM
Source:[InstaForex](https://www.instaforex.com/forex-news/2776156)

**Annual inflation comes in at 6.3% in May | Namibia Economist**
The Namibia Statistics Agency reported that the annual inflation rate rose to 6.3% in May 2023, up from 5.4% in May 2022. Food and non‑alcoholic beverages were the largest contributors, increasing 12.5% and adding 2.4 percentage points to the CPI. Alcoholic beverages and tobacco followed, rising 7.5% and contributing 1.0 percentage point. On a month‑on‑month basis, inflation was 0.2%, down from 0.4% the previous month. At the zonal level, Zone 1 (Kavango East, Kavango West, Kunene, Ohangwena, Omusati, Oshana, Oshikoto, Otjozondjupa, Zambezi) and Zone 3 (Kharas, Erongo, Hardap, Omaheke) recorded the highest annual inflation of 6.3%, while Zone 2 (Khomas) had the lowest at 6.2%. Price analysis showed that consumers in Zone 2 paid the highest price for a 750 ml bottle of pure sunflower oil at N$36.86, compared with N$35.38 in Zone 1 and N$34.42 in Zone 3. For brown bread, Zone 3 paid the lowest price of N$13.24, whereas Zone 2 paid the highest at N$14.33. 'The annual inflation rate stood at 6.3% in May 2023 compared to 5.4% in May 2022,' the agency added.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 26, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[economist.com.na](https://economist.com.na/79954/extra/annual-inflation-comes-in-at-6-3-in-may/)

**Fall in transport, furniture costs pushed Namibia's yearly inflation down to 3.2% in August**
Namibia's annual inflation fell to 3.2% in August from 3.5% in July, according to the Namibia Statistics Agency (NSA). The decline was driven by easing transport, furniture and household equipment costs. Core inflation for August stood at 3.6%. NSA spokesperson Mirjam Shihepo said the figures show largely stable consumer prices across most regions, though local supply and demand variations exist. The central bank had projected August inflation at 3.6% and forecast 3.9% for September and 4.0% for October. It also released baseline estimates that inflation will average 3.8% in 2025 and 4.2% in 2026, 'reflecting a downwards revision of 0.1%.'
Original language: en
Publish date: September 12, 2025 12:36 PM
Source:[bne IntelliNews](https://www.intellinews.com/fall-in-transport-furniture-costs-pushed-namibia-s-yearly-inflation-down-to-3-2-in-august-400894/)
